trans-unit.source: Consistency levels in DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Consistency levels in DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB has four consistency levels with associated performance levels to help application developers make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB has four consistency levels with associated performance levels to help application developers make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.

trans-unit.source: Developers are often faced with the challenge of choosing between the two extremes of strong and eventual consistency.
trans-unit.target: Developers are often faced with the challenge of choosing between the two extremes of strong and eventual consistency.

trans-unit.source: The reality is that there are multiple consistency click-stops between these two extremes.
trans-unit.target: The reality is that there are multiple consistency click-stops between these two extremes.

trans-unit.source: In most real world scenarios, applications benefit from making fine grained trade-offs between consistency, availability, and latency.
trans-unit.target: In most real world scenarios, applications benefit from making fine grained trade-offs between consistency, availability, and latency.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB offers four well-defined consistency levels with associated performance levels.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB offers four well-defined consistency levels with associated performance levels.

trans-unit.source: This allows application developers to make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.
trans-unit.target: This allows application developers to make predictable consistency-availability-latency trade-offs.

trans-unit.source: All system resources, including database accounts, databases, collections, users, and permissions are always strongly consistent for reads and queries.
trans-unit.target: All system resources, including database accounts, databases, collections, users, and permissions are always strongly consistent for reads and queries.

trans-unit.source: The consistency levels apply only to the user defined resources.
trans-unit.target: The consistency levels apply only to the user defined resources.

trans-unit.source: For queries and read operations on user defined resources, including documents, attachments, stored procedures, triggers, and UDFs, DocumentDB offers four distinct consistency levels:
trans-unit.target: For queries and read operations on user defined resources, including documents, attachments, stored procedures, triggers, and UDFs, DocumentDB offers four distinct consistency levels:

trans-unit.source: Strong
trans-unit.target: Strong

trans-unit.source: Bounded staleness
trans-unit.target: Bounded staleness

trans-unit.source: Session
trans-unit.target: Session

trans-unit.source: Eventual
trans-unit.target: Eventual

trans-unit.source: These granular, well-defined consistency levels allow you to make sound trade-offs between consistency, availability, and performance.
trans-unit.target: These granular, well-defined consistency levels allow you to make sound trade-offs between consistency, availability, and performance.

trans-unit.source: These consistency levels are backed by predictable performance levels ensuring consistent results for your application.
trans-unit.target: These consistency levels are backed by predictable performance levels ensuring consistent results for your application.

trans-unit.source: You can configure a default consistency level on your database account that applies to all the collections (across all of the databases) under your database account.
trans-unit.target: You can configure a default consistency level on your database account that applies to all the collections (across all of the databases) under your database account.

trans-unit.source: By default, all reads and queries issued against the user defined resources will use the default consistency level specified on the database account.
trans-unit.target: By default, all reads and queries issued against the user defined resources will use the default consistency level specified on the database account.

trans-unit.source: However, you can lower the consistency level of a specific read/query request by specifying [x-ms-consistency-level] request header.
trans-unit.target: However, you can lower the consistency level of a specific read/query request by specifying [x-ms-consistency-level] request header.

trans-unit.source: There are four types of consistency levels supported by the DocumentDB replication protocol - these are briefly described below.
trans-unit.target: There are four types of consistency levels supported by the DocumentDB replication protocol - these are briefly described below.

trans-unit.source: In a future release, we intend to support overriding the default consistency level on a per collection basis.
trans-unit.target: In a future release, we intend to support overriding the default consistency level on a per collection basis.

trans-unit.source: Strong: Strong consistency guarantees that a write is only visible after it is committed durably by the majority quorum of replicas.
trans-unit.target: Strong: Strong consistency guarantees that a write is only visible after it is committed durably by the majority quorum of replicas.

trans-unit.source: A write is either synchronously committed durably by both the primary and the quorum of secondaries or it is aborted.
trans-unit.target: A write is either synchronously committed durably by both the primary and the quorum of secondaries or it is aborted.

trans-unit.source: A read is always acknowledged by the majority read quorum - a client can never see an uncommitted or partial write and is always guaranteed to read the latest acknowledged write.
trans-unit.target: A read is always acknowledged by the majority read quorum - a client can never see an uncommitted or partial write and is always guaranteed to read the latest acknowledged write.

trans-unit.source: Strong consistency provides absolute guarantees on data consistency, but offers the lowest level of read and write performance.
trans-unit.target: Strong consistency provides absolute guarantees on data consistency, but offers the lowest level of read and write performance.

trans-unit.source: Bounded staleness: Bounded staleness consistency guarantees the total order of propagation of writes with the possibility that reads lag behind writes by at most K prefixes.
trans-unit.target: Bounded staleness: Bounded staleness consistency guarantees the total order of propagation of writes with the possibility that reads lag behind writes by at most K prefixes.

trans-unit.source: The read is always acknowledged by a majority quorum of replicas.
trans-unit.target: The read is always acknowledged by a majority quorum of replicas.

trans-unit.source: The response of a read request specifies its relative freshness (in terms of K).
trans-unit.target: The response of a read request specifies its relative freshness (in terms of K).

trans-unit.source: Bounded staleness provides more predictable behavior for read consistency while offering the lowest latency writes.
trans-unit.target: Bounded staleness provides more predictable behavior for read consistency while offering the lowest latency writes.

trans-unit.source: As reads are acknowledged by a majority quorum, read latency is not the lowest offered by the system.
trans-unit.target: As reads are acknowledged by a majority quorum, read latency is not the lowest offered by the system.

trans-unit.source: Bounded staleness guarantees monotonic reads only on explicit read requests.
trans-unit.target: Bounded staleness guarantees monotonic reads only on explicit read requests.

trans-unit.source: The echoed server response for write requests does not offer bounded staleness guarantees.
trans-unit.target: The echoed server response for write requests does not offer bounded staleness guarantees.

trans-unit.source: Session: Unlike the global consistency models offered by strong and bounded staleness consistency levels, “session” consistency is tailored for a specific client session.
trans-unit.target: Session: Unlike the global consistency models offered by strong and bounded staleness consistency levels, “session” consistency is tailored for a specific client session.

trans-unit.source: Session consistency is usually sufficient since it provides guaranteed monotonic reads, and writes and ability to read your own writes.
trans-unit.target: Session consistency is usually sufficient since it provides guaranteed monotonic reads, and writes and ability to read your own writes.

trans-unit.source: A read request for session consistency is issued against a replica that can serve the client requested version (part of the session cookie).
trans-unit.target: A read request for session consistency is issued against a replica that can serve the client requested version (part of the session cookie).

trans-unit.source: Session consistency provides predictable read data consistency for a session while offering the lowest latency writes.
trans-unit.target: Session consistency provides predictable read data consistency for a session while offering the lowest latency writes.

trans-unit.source: Reads are also low latency as except in the rare cases, the read will be served by a single replica.
trans-unit.target: Reads are also low latency as except in the rare cases, the read will be served by a single replica.

trans-unit.source: Eventual: Eventual consistency is the weakest form of consistency wherein a client may get the values which are older than the ones it had seen before, over time.
trans-unit.target: Eventual: Eventual consistency is the weakest form of consistency wherein a client may get the values which are older than the ones it had seen before, over time.

trans-unit.source: In the absence of any further writes, the replicas within the group will eventually converge.
trans-unit.target: In the absence of any further writes, the replicas within the group will eventually converge.

trans-unit.source: The read request is served by any secondary index.
trans-unit.target: The read request is served by any secondary index.

trans-unit.source: Eventual consistency provides the weakest read consistency but offers the lowest latency for both reads and writes.
trans-unit.target: Eventual consistency provides the weakest read consistency but offers the lowest latency for both reads and writes.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Preview portal, click Browse All.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Preview portal, click Browse All.

trans-unit.source: In the Browse All blade, click DocumentDB Accounts.
trans-unit.target: In the Browse All blade, click DocumentDB Accounts.

trans-unit.source: In the DocumentDB Accounts blade, select the database account to modify.
trans-unit.target: In the DocumentDB Accounts blade, select the database account to modify.

trans-unit.source: In the account blade, in the Configuration lens, click the Default Consistency tile.
trans-unit.target: In the account blade, in the Configuration lens, click the Default Consistency tile.

trans-unit.source: Select the new consistency level and click Save.
trans-unit.target: Select the new consistency level and click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screen shot highlighting the Default Consistency tile, the consistency settings and the Save button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screen shot highlighting the Default Consistency tile, the consistency settings and the Save button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: By default, for user defined resources, the consistency level of the queries is the same as the reads.
trans-unit.target: By default, for user defined resources, the consistency level of the queries is the same as the reads.

trans-unit.source: By default, the index is updated synchronously on each insert, replace, or delete of a document to the collection.
trans-unit.target: By default, the index is updated synchronously on each insert, replace, or delete of a document to the collection.

trans-unit.source: This enables the queries to honor the same consistency level as that of the document reads.
trans-unit.target: This enables the queries to honor the same consistency level as that of the document reads.

trans-unit.source: While DocumentDB is write optimized and supports sustained volumes of document writes along with synchronous index maintenance and serving consistent queries, you can configure certain collections to update their index lazily.
trans-unit.target: While DocumentDB is write optimized and supports sustained volumes of document writes along with synchronous index maintenance and serving consistent queries, you can configure certain collections to update their index lazily.

trans-unit.source: Lazy indexing further boosts the write performance and is ideal for bulk ingestion scenarios when a workload is primarily read-heavy.
trans-unit.target: Lazy indexing further boosts the write performance and is ideal for bulk ingestion scenarios when a workload is primarily read-heavy.

trans-unit.source: Indexing Mode
trans-unit.target: Indexing Mode

trans-unit.source: Reads
trans-unit.target: Reads

trans-unit.source: Queries
trans-unit.target: Queries

trans-unit.source: Consistent (default)
trans-unit.target: Consistent (default)

trans-unit.source: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual
trans-unit.target: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual

trans-unit.source: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual
trans-unit.target: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual

trans-unit.source: Lazy
trans-unit.target: Lazy

trans-unit.source: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual
trans-unit.target: Select from Strong, Bounded staleness, Session, or Eventual

trans-unit.source: Eventual
trans-unit.target: Eventual

trans-unit.source: As with read requests, you can lower the consistency level of a specific query request by specifying the [x-ms-consistency-level] request header.
trans-unit.target: As with read requests, you can lower the consistency level of a specific query request by specifying the [x-ms-consistency-level] request header.

trans-unit.target: If you'd like to do more reading about consistency levels and tradeoffs, we recommend the following resources:
